contents.text: Updated April 27, 2018: Clairo released a new track and video
"4EVER"
and announced her EP "diary 001" will be out May 25.
Four months into 2018, it's safe to say that Clairo is having a year: The DIY pop artist has opened for
Tyler, The Creator
; became the face of Spotify's "Bedroom Pop" playlist; and made the lineup for
Lollapalooza
in August. And there's no doubt more is coming, especially after her latest video, for "Flaming Hot Cheetos," featuring a cameo from
Cuco

, compiled more than 1.3 million views on YouTube. For those of you who have only heard that track (or fans up for a spirited debate), we dug through four years of Clairo's SoundCloud for the songs we felt provided the best sense of her body of work to date — presented in no particular order. Time to press play.

If, for whatever reason, you had a dream about the Enchantment Under the Sea Dance from "Back to the Future" that took place present day, you wouldn't hear "Earth Angel" by Marvin Berry and the Starlighters playing, you'd hear Clairo and a rendition of this. It toes that fine, almost impossible line that is both current and timeless.

This one’s just over a year young, but it seamlessly replicates the purity and simplicity found in the production of her earlier entries. The verses call back to those early heartaches experienced in youth and trying too hard to measure up to another person's unrealistic expectations.

Most every Clairo track has a dreamy feel to it — some more than others, but this one most of all. She’s bummed over a relationship gone bad, one she cared about a bit more than the others that have come and gone without a whole lot of hurt or regret. It’s the kind of ache you can’t catch a break from whether you’re awake, asleep or somewhere in-between.

This track from 2015 was the first in which Clairo's vocals clearly cut through. They're a bit cleaner than on some of her earlier bedroom pop fare — and in that way, "bubble gum" seems like the first moment Clairo revealed herself. It's still striking how well her voice glides along the track.

She's got a great sound here, almost reminiscent of Cults. Her guitar takes center stage (and here's to hoping she explores that more in the future). At the same time, she's got that late-'50s, early-'60s pop sound down.

title.text: Viaja para as águas do Oeste australiano em Margaret River com o No Contest

contents.text: A edição de 2018 do Margaret River Pro vai ser para sempre recordado como o evento que não chegou a acontecer. Depois de duas rondas de competição entre os homens, e das mulheres chegarem aos quartos-de-final, um par de tubarões fez uma série de ataques na Costa Oeste da Austrália e obrigou ao cancelamento da competição. Os pontos e os prémios em dinheiro foram distribuídos pelos atletas que ainda estavam em prova.

Foi uma pena, porque os dias de competição e de free surfing estavam a aproveitar um swell impressionante; a habitual combinação de grandes restaurantes e tubos espectaculares de North Point e The Box estava a dar os frutos habituais.
No último episódio da trilogia australiana do No Contest,
Jacob Wooden
e
Dylan Roberts
falaram com o spotter de tubarões
Dave Delroy-Carr
e encontraram-se com a lenda local e talento do freesurf
Jay Davies
. Das rochas apanharam também os melhores momentos de
Michel Bourez
Adriano de Souza
Julian Wilson
Jordy Smith
e
Mikey Wright
, antes de se divertirem com os outros atletas do Circuito Mundial.

Margaret River teve tudo menos o resultado final, mas certamente o futuro vai ser melhor. Vê o vídeo final da passagem do No Contest pela costa australiana e prepara-te para a ação no Rio de Janeiro, a próxima paragem do surf de topo.

contents.text: La edición 2018 del Margaret River Pro será recordada como la prueba que se tuvo que anular. Después de dos rondas de la competición masculina, un par de ataques cerca de donde se desarrollaba el evento obligó a dar por finalizada la prueba. Los puntos y los premios en metálico se repartieron entre los atletas que continuaban en la competición.

La cancelación fue una pena pues las olas ofrecieron un espectáculo de primer nivel. Desde los tubos en el North Point y en The Box, hasta el disfrute de los viñedos y la fauna local, el lugar contaba con multitud de atractivos.
Para este trabajo
Jacob Wooden
y
Dylan Roberts
se unieron a
Dave Delroy-Carr
. Nos pusimos en las rocas para filmar a talentos como Jay Davies, Michel Bourez, Adriano de Souza, Julian Wilson, Jordy Smith y Mikey Wright.

La acción en Margaret River ha sido impresionante. Esperamos verte muy pronto en Río de Janeiro, donde se celebrará el evento de Brasil. Mientras tanto da al botón del “play” del vídeo de arriba para que disfrutes de lo mejor de Australia Occidental.

teaser.text: Grandes olas y grandes bichos pues hubo que cancelar el evento final de No Contest en Australia debido a los tiburones. Disfruta aquí de todo lo que ocurrió entre bastidores.

contents.text: The 2018 edition of the Margaret River Pro will long be remembered as the event that never was. After two rounds of men's competition and with the ladies making it up to the quarterfinals, a pair of shark attacks just up the coast saw competition abandoned, with points and prize money split between those still remaining in the draw.

The event being scratched is a shame, as outside of competition the world's best made the most of a few incredible days of action as the swell well and truly came to the party. From heaving barrels at North Point and The Box, and the usual selection of fine dining, wineries and wildlife, it was a window that provided so much yet so little at the same time.
In the final episode of
"No Contest"
for the Australian contest trilogy, our man
Jacob Wooden
and
Stab's
Dylan Roberts
caught up with trials winner and shark spotter
Dave Delroy-Carr
and hung out with local legend and global freesurf talent
Jay Davies
. Naturally we posted up in the rocks to shoot all the best action from guys like
Michel Bourez
Adriano de Souza
Julian Wilson
Jordy Smith
and
Mikey Wright
, as well as grilling the rest of the world tour caravan on all sorts of fun and games.

Margaret River had everything but a result, and we hope in the future the tour keeps including the west coast in its lap of Oz. We've had a blast these past six weeks bringing "No Contest" together, and can't wait to see you again soon in Rio de Janeiro for the Brazilian event. Till then, hit play on the video at the top of this page and soak up the best from the west.

contents.text: April's been a busy month for rap news.
Kanye's
tweeting about new music and more,
Drake's
swapping his own No. 1 hit for another No. 1 hit and
Kendrick's

busy framing his Pulitzer certificate. But rappers big and small, young and old, local and global continued to drop mixtapes at such an unprecedented clip that even the 24-hour news cycle could barely keep up.

Whether new projects came from signed artists becoming free agents again (Lil Durk), hyped rappers taking unexpected swerves (Princess Nokia) or rising emcees pushing things into darker territory (070 Shake), the
mixtape
game delivered so much heat this month that we almost didn't notice how much extra snow was still falling.

Smokepurpp hasn't taken off like some of his contemporaries in the South Florida scene. While 2017's "Audi" was a scene-defining banger, his debut mixtape "Deadstar" didn't live up to the hype the track ushered in. But he's at least making moves in the right direction, starting 2018 with a tight, 11-song tape called "Bless Yo Trap." Rather than trying to recapture the essence of his biggest hit, Smokepurpp hitches his Audi to the established star power of Canadian producer Murda Beatz, a former in-house producer for Migos who has pumped out hit after hit for the likes of Drake, Gucci Mane and Travis Scott. While Purpp can't help but still mimic his peers (Lil Pump on "Do Not Disturb," Playboi Carti on "Wockstar") — which only strengthens the comparisons of "Audi" to XXXTentacion's seminal cut "Look At Me!" — it's only a matter of time before a Smokepurpp track just sounds like a Smokepurpp track. For now, the simulation is as real as it gets.

Major labels aren't for everyone. Unless you're an already proven "brand" like Kanye or Drake, it's nearly impossible to achieve artistic autonomy under major label deals. Lil Durk, drill mainstay and one of the most reliable rappers out of Chicago, is among the latest to suffer from major label meddling, and it ultimately resulted in him splitting to go solo. "Just Cause Y'all Waited," his 12th mixtape, is Durk's first independent release since becoming a free agent and arrives after five years with Def Jam. Throughout its 12 relatively compact tracks, Durk doesn't show any new sides, per se, but he wisely avoids the crossover concessions of Def Jam debut "Remember My Name" and simply capitalizes on what he's always done best: street narratives embedded in dour party music.

Canada's got a new crooner. He's a young, under-21 artist from Edmonton who goes by FRVRFRIDAY (pronounced "forever Friday"). His latest, titled "WHOISFRIDAY," is a swirling six-track mixtape that flexes a "Late Nights"-Jeremih meets OVO Sound vibe through silky vocal workouts that cut through the tape’s minimalist production with poise and sensuality. However, unlike Jeremih or artists from the OVO Sound crew, FRVRFRIDAY's not only behind the mic on each cut, but he's also on the boards producing, showcasing a seasoned confidence beyond his years while charting his wide-eyed ambition. It’s the mark of a precocious artist whose only possible trajectory at this point is skyward. It's a deadly combination and there's no telling what he can do once he finds a sound that's truly his own.

As we continue to wait for Warhol.SS’s debut full-length "Chest Pains" to drop, the Chicago rapper has dispatched yet another new mixtape, titled "Broken Records." This time, Warhol.SS taps Dayton's BOOFBOIICY for six new tracks, each featuring a different (and mostly unknown) producer, yet all cohering into a single murky backdrop. Clarity has never been one of Warhol.SS's strengths and here he doubles down by riding beats into the gutter while BOOFBOIICY mumbles his way into a narcotic haze. The whole thing's sloppy and unmastered, off-the-cuff and off-center, totally unprofessional in the best way possible. More mixtapes need to sound like this.

By now, classic New York rap beats are inherently no less fresh than Atlanta trap. But because we conceptualize music on a timeline rather than on a continuum, mixtapes like Conway's "Blakk Tape" are often crammed into the false narrative of being "throwbacks." Truth is, "Blakk Tape" is simply a re-calibration of a sound that never left to begin with, one whose longevity itself proves its worth. That the Buffalo rapper can enact such an invigorating, lively permutation of the classic NY sound speaks to his ability to feel his way through production in intimate, intuitive ways, hitting registers that feel both familiar and new. It's effortlessly raw and welcomingly gritty, which is especially appropriate for a tape designed, as Conway puts it, "for the streets."
After straight-up destroying the mixtape template with "1992,"
our favorite mixtape from 2016

, Princess Nokia returns with what she dubs ... an "emo mixtape." Sure, the worlds of rap and emo have been commingling as of late with the likes of Lil Peep and Lil Xan, but "A Girl Cried Red" is in a league of its own. Nokia — AKA New York rapper Destiny Frasqueri — doesn't simply sample rock, drop confessional bars and slap on the emo tag; she embarks on a truly weird yet lighthearted exploration of these two seemingly opposing styles, turning a nascent hybridized sound world into a bizarre mutation, with no concern for what's "cool" or even how it might be received. The risk here is that she'll end up alienating audiences on all sides, including the die-hards, but this sort of fearlessness has long been a mark of our most treasured artists.

Kanye's reactivated Twitter account has been getting the headlines these days, but it's his G.O.O.D. Music imprint that's been on fire all year. Following fellow signee Valee's excellent "Good Job, You Found Me" EP, Ye's label dropped 070 Shake's "Glitter" mixtape at the tail end of last month, and it's a wonderfully cohesive work, especially surprising for an artist who hadn't recorded a song before 2015. But what isn't surprising is Shake's quick rise through the ranks. The New Jersey native — part of the 11-strong 070 collective — has the ambition and talent to transcend the prototypical artist/producer dynamic, coiling her flexible vocal theatrics around propulsive, thoroughly unique beats provided by The Kompetition with a natural, easy flow. Nothing's easy about this listen though: Shake plunges into dark places, taking on heavy topics like addiction, depression and sexuality, yet she emerges with something like catharsis, making the whole emotional trip well worth the energy spent.

contents.text: Dizem que a única coisa que se ganha ao olhar para o passado é um torcicolo, mas
Ross Clarke-Jones

tem uma opinião bastante diferente: aos 51 anos, a lenda do surf acredita que a modalidade precisa de olhar para trás e recordar o lado divertido que levou centenas de pessoas a subir para a prancha pela primeira vez. Recusando a ideia de que os atletas não devem ser atores, Clarke-Jones juntou-se aos jovens talentos
Kanoa Igarashi
Leo Fioravanti
e
Caroline Marks
para homenagear o mais louco filme do mundo do surf: 'Mad Wax', uma produção tipicamente dos anos 80 do século XX que ajudou a definir a cultura desta modalidade.

'Go Mad' é uma curta que recupera a lenda de um wax mágico que transporta os surfistas no tempo e no espaço para os spots mais incríveis do planeta. Exatamente 30 anos depois do sucesso de 'Mad Wax', a nova geração do surf descobre a história que fez sucesso nos leitores de cassetes VHS - e de Beta, um tesouro perdido do século passado.

“Eu via filmes de surf nos cinemas, com ondas perfeitas em cada Pipeline. Lembro-me de pensar 'isto é bom durante um bocado, mas depois torna-se aborrecido'. A evolução chegou com filmes como 'Mad Wax' e 'Kong's Island', que mostravam a essência do surf: a diversão!", explica Ross Clark-Jones, estrela de 'Mad Wax'.
Deixa-te transportar por uns momentos para o passado e recorda o glorioso surf dos anos 80 com este lendário filme:

Tudo nasceu no verão de 1987, quando o desporto de nicho conhecido como surf estava a um pequeno passo de ganhar reconhecimento global; as marcas de roupa deste desporto ganhavam fama, mas os atletas eram ainda desconhecidos para a maior parte das pessoas. É então que surge 'Mad Wax', um filme que adaptou ligeiramente o título de uma saga bastante mais conhecida - 'Mad Max', a série que deu fama mundial a Mel Gibson - e que contava a história de um pequeno bloco triangular de cera para pranchas com a invulgar capacidade de transportar os surfistas no tempo e no espaço. O conceito era simples: os surfistas passavam a indispensável cera nas pranchas e com um efeito sonoro clássico viajavam instantaneamente para o spot dos seus sonhos - ou neste caso, o melhor spot para o qual a equipa de filmagens tinha dinheiro para viajar.

O filme teve como estrelas os grandes nomes do surf da época: o bicampeão do Mundo Tom Carroll, Gary 'Kong' Elkerton e o próprio Ross Clarke-Jones. O filme ficou conhecido pelas interpretações muito abaixo da média e por ter dado fama aos participantes; 30 anos depois, Clarke-Jones pode orgulhar-se de ter sido o primeiro não-havaiano a ganhar o The Eddie, e de ter ficado em segundo lugar na competição aos 49 anos, apenas atrás do Campeão do Mundo John John Florence.

O surf de Ross Clarke-Jones cresceu ao longo dos anos, com prestações lendárias na Nazaré, mas a capacidade de representar ficou igual. Felizmente, isso ajuda a dar mais encanto a 'Go Mad' e a criar uma curta icónica que ajuda a nova geração a perceber a cultura original das ondas.

Claro que não poderia ser um tributo aos anos 80 sem a banda sonora da época, cedida pela banda australiana responsável pelas músicas originais: os GANGgajang. Vê as canções originais e muitos outras músicas que marcaram o mundo do surf, numa playlist de Spotify criada em colaboração pela
Red Bull Music
e pela
Red Bull Surf
'Go Mad' foi coproduzido pela
World Wide Mind
e realizado pelo responsável pelo filme de surf de 2013 'Drift'.

title.text: Ouve no Spotify: 'Go Mad' e as canções que ajudaram a criar a cultura do surf
Go Mad: o wax que te faz teletransportar

rrn:content:ext:context:social.text: Go Mad: Perde a cabeça com Clarke-Jones e a cera mágica

rrn:content:ext:context:seo.text: Go Mad: Perde a cabeça com Clarke-Jones e a cera mágica

teaser.text: Existe maneira melhor de regressar aos loucos anos 80 do surf do que um filme ficcional com Ross Clarke-Jones, Kanoa Igarashi, Caroline Marks e Leo Fioravanti?

contents.text: Dicen que lo único que obtienes al mirar hacia atrás es un dolor en el cuello. Pero intenta contárselo a la leyenda de las olas grandes
Ross Clarke-Jones
, quien a los 51 años considera que es en el pasado donde ha de buscarse para redescubrir la diversión que hizo que la gente realmente quisiera subirse a una tabla de surf.
El caso es que el bueno de Ross se ha juntado con los jóvenes cracks
Kanoa Igarashi, Leo Fioravanti
y
Caroline Marks
para rendir homenaje a la película más loca del surf, "Mad Wax", aquella que causó sensación en los años 80.

"'Go Mad' es una forma muy divertida de darle a todos una mirada única al surf y darnos la oportunidad de mostrar nuestras habilidades de actuación también", explica Ross entre risas. "¡No hay nada más parecido y eso es lo que hace que sea especial ser parte de esto!"

Corría el verano de 1987 y un pequeño deporte llamado surf estaba en la cúspide de la popularidad. La industria de la ropa de surf empezaba a resonar, aunque las marcas y los surfistas seguirían siendo en gran parte desconocidos.
Mad Wax

tomó prestado su título de una franquicia cinematográfica algo más conocida, y fue construida alrededor de un triángulo de parafina de surf con poderes de teletransporte. ¿La esencia? Los surfistas frotan su tabla con esta pastilla de parafina mágica, imaginan dónde quieren surfear en el mundo y con un efecto de sonido de los 80 y algo de magia para el cine, son inmediatamente arrastrados al lugar de sus sueños.

Solía ​​ver películas de surf en el cine, siempre oleadas y oleadas de Pipeline perfecto. Recuerdo haber pensado: esto es bueno para las primeras olas, pero luego se vuelve aburrido. La evolución que surgió de películas como 'Mad Wax' y 'Kong's Island' parecía más representativa de lo que era el surf... ¡divertirse!
Junto a Clarke-Jones,
Mad Wax
también contó con algunos de los nombres más importantes del surf del momento, incluido el bicampeón mundial
Tom Carroll
y
Gary "Kong" Elkerton
. 30 años después, Ross Clarke-Jones sigue en la cresta de la ola como uno de los más respetados surfers de olas grandes en activo. Entre sus logros están ser el primer no-hawaiano en ganar el
Quiksilver Eddie Aikau
, entre otras muchas gestas en olas como
Nazaré
o
The Right

title.text: La parafina mágica que te transportará a los 80

rrn:content:ext:context:social.text: La parafina mágica que te transportará a los 80

rrn:content:ext:context:seo.text: Go Mad: la parafina mágica del surf de los 80

teaser.text: Un divertido homenaje a la era más peculiar de la historia del surf.

contents.text: They say the only thing you get from looking back is a sore neck. But try telling that to big-wave legend
Ross Clarke-Jones
, who at 51 reckons the past is where
surfing

needs to look if it’s to rediscover the fun that made people wanna climb on a board in the first place. They also say never to make surfers act. Well, RCJ has nixed that, too, commandeering the services of World Tour youngsters
Kanoa Igarashi
Leo Fioravanti
and
Caroline Marks
to pay homage to surfing’s wildest ever film, "Mad Wax" — the very definition of 1980s, erm, cool?

Yep, just when you thought surfing was safe from Hollywood reboots comes Go Mad, a tongue-in-cheek all ’80s digital short that introduces magic teleporting wax to a whole new generation of surfers 30 years after "Mad Wax" hit VCR — and beta!

“I used to watch surf movies in theaters and watch wave after wave of perfect Pipeline,” said RCJ, the star of the original video. “And I remember thinking, this is good for the first few waves, but then it gets boring. The evolution that came from films like "Mad Wax" and Kong’s Island felt like it was more expressive of what surfing was all about … having fun!”
In the spirit of teleporting, let’s take a quick detour down memory lane.

Twas the summer of 1987, and a little sport called surfing was on the cusp of mainstream popularity. The surf apparel industry was just one more unusually tight pair of button up boardshorts away from exploding, and brands and surfers alike remained largely unknown to the mainstream. Enter "Mad Wax": a surf film that borrowed its title from a somewhat better known movie franchise, and was built around a triangle block of surf wax with teleportation powers. The gist? Surfers rub the wax on the board, imagine where they want to surf in the world, and with a 1980s-sound effect and some movie magic, are immediately zapped to the location of their dreams — or more realistically, wherever the budget would allow the crew to shoot. A perfect device for low budget surf films.

It starred some of the biggest names in surfing at the time, including two-time world champ Tom Carroll, and Gary “Kong” Elkerton. It also featured some of the worst acting ever witnessed by theater-goers. Some 30 years later, RCJ is renowned the word over as a big-wave madman, being the first non-hawaiian to win The Eddie, and runner-up to John John Florence in 2016 at 49 years of age.

His surfing has gone from strength to strength. His acting however, hasn’t. Making "Go Mad" all the more fun and representative of the wild Aussie’s mantra — take your surfing seriously, not yourself. It’s an outlook world tour rookie Marks was more than happy to embrace, despite her admirable chops in front of the lens.

“'Go Mad' is a really fun way of giving everyone a unique look at surfing and giving us the chance show off our acting skills too,” she said with a laugh. “There is nothing else like it out there and that’s what makes it special to be a part of!”
Igarashi and Fioravanti said they’d prefer their acting to do the talking for them …

Of course, no 1980s tribute would be complete without the tunes of the time. And "Go Mad" has the best courtesy of GANGgajang, the Australian band that scored the original to have the Mad Wax soundtrack voted one of the most definitive in surf vid history. Check out the track and a whole slew of surfing’s most definitive tunes here, in our Spotify playlist curated by
Red Bull Music
and
Red Bull Surf
. It features tunes everywhere from "Endless Summer" through "Momentum," "Good Times," "Lost Atlas," "View From a Blue Moon" and a bunch in between.
Go Mad was co-produced by
World Wide Mind
and directed by the director responsible for 2013 feature surf drama "Drift".

contents.text: 「過去を振り返っても良いことはひとつもない」と言われる。
しかし、現在51歳のビッグウェーブサーフィンのレジェンド、
ロス・クラーク・ジョーンズ
の考えは違う。彼はサーフボードに乗る楽しさを再発見するには、過去を振り返る必要があると考えている。
「サーファーに演技をさせてはいけない」とも言われる。
ロス・クラーク・ジョーンズはこの言葉にも同意しない。先日、彼はワールドツアーを牽引する若手3人 －
五十嵐カノア
レオ・フィオラバンティ
キャロライン・マークス
－ を捕まえて、1980年代そのものと言えるサーフィン史上に残るサーフムービー『
Mad Wax
』のオマージュ映像の撮影に参加させた。
そう、誰もが「サーフシーンはハリウッドのリブート作品とは無縁だ」と思った矢先、
1980年代風デジタルショートムービー『Go Mad』
が制作され、『Mad Wax』がVHSとベータでリリースされてから30年後に新世代サーファーたちへ “あのワックス” を授けたのだ！
『Mad Wax』で
主演
を務めたロス・クラーク・ジョーンズは、自分のカルトサーフムービーについて次のようにコメントしている。
「昔はよく映画館でサーフムービーを観ていたんだ。パイプラインのパーフェクトな波がスクリーンに次から次へと現れていた。だが、今振り返ってみると、波ばかりだったからすぐに飽きていたんだ」
「だから、そのあとに登場した『Mad Wax』や『Kong’s Island』のようなサーフムービーは、“楽しむ” というサーフィンの本質をもっと良く捉えているように思えたよ」
『Mad Wax』はどんなサーフムービーだったのだろうか？　簡単に振り返ってみよう。
。サーフィンと呼ばれる小さなスポーツがメインストリームの人気を獲得しようとしていた。サーフアパレルはまだ世間に浸透しておらず、サーファーの多くは無名だった。その中で公開されたのが『Mad Wax』だった。
誰もが知っている
あのアクション映画シリーズ
をもじったタイトルが付けられたこのサーフムービーは、テレポート能力を秘めた
三角形のワックス
を中心に据えていた。
簡単にまとめれば、『Mad Wax』は、サーファーがこのマジックワックスをボードに塗り、サーフィンしたい場所をイメージすると、1980年代丸出しのサウンド＆ムービーエフェクトと共にそこへテレポートできるという内容だった。
しかし、現実を言えば、その行き先は制作予算が許す範囲に限られていた。言ってしまえば、このワックスは、低予算サーフムービーにパーフェクトな存在だったのだ。
『Mad Wax』には、ワールドチャンピオンに2度輝いた経験を持つ
トム・キャロル
や
ゲーリー・エルカートン
を含む、当時のシーンを代表するサーファーたちがフィーチャーされていた。しかし、同時に映画史上に残る “
最低の演技
” もフィーチャーされていた。
このサーフムービーが世に出てから30年以上が経った今、ハワイ以外のサーファーとして初めて
“エディ・アイカウ
” を制し、2016年には
ながら
ジョン・ジョン・フローレンス
と互角に渡り合って準優勝を勝ち取るなど、数々の偉業を成し遂げてきたロス・クラーク・ジョーンズは、ビッグウェーブサーフィンのレジェンドとして尊敬を集めている。
ロス・クラーク・ジョーンズの
サーフィンは
年と共に
成長した
のだ。しかし、彼の
演技力は
まるで
成長していない
というわけで、『Go Mad』を最大限楽しみたいなら、このオーストラリア出身のレジェンドの座右の銘と同じく、「
人ではなくサーフィンに集中する
」必要がある。この言葉は、ワールドツアールーキーのキャロライン・マークスも心に刻みつけているものだが、彼女の演技は問題ない。
撮影を終えたマークスは「『Go Mad』は、サーフィンをいつもとは違う面白い視点から観ることができる作品なの。わたしたちの演技力をアピールするチャンスにもなったけどね（笑）。似たような作品は他にひとつもないし、参加できたことをスペシャルに思えるわ！」とコメントしている。
一方、
五十嵐カノア
と
レオ・フィオラバンティ
は自分たちの演技には触れたくないというコメントを残している…。
さて、話を戻すが、1980年代のトリビュートは当時の音楽がなければ完成しない。『Go Mad』にも、当時サーフムービー史上最高のサウンドトラックとして評価された『Mad Wax』のサウンドトラックを手掛けたオーストラリアのバンド
GANGgajang
が参加している。
『Go Mad』本編をチェックしたあとは、
Red Bull Music
と
Red Bull Surf
がコンパイルした
Spotifyプレイリスト
でサーフシーンと強く結びついているトラックの数々をチェックしよう！　New Order、Iggy Pop、Sonic Youthなどのトラックが満載だ。
World Wide Mindとの共同制作で進められた『Go Mad』は、2013年に公開されたサーフムービー『ドリフト』の監督が指揮を執った。

contents.text: Jared Goff
is the star
quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams
, but for one magical spring day, he was a transfer named Dreaj Foge (pronounced Dray) into the Ventura College football team in Southern California, a powerhouse program in the JUCO ranks.
How, you ask?

In what could go down as the football prank of the year, Goff and the coaching staff at Ventura College tricked the team into believing he was the hotshot newcomer eyeing the starting QB job, which would break the hearts of the team’s actual quarterbacks looking to get four-year rides. Needless to say, the real QBs on the roster were none too pleased!
When Goff began slinging balls all over the field in 7-on-7 drills, the real drama started.
Watch the video above to see how the prank unfolded.

Head Coach Steven Mooshagian and director of football operations Robert Mooshagian (yes, a father/son duo!), were obviously in on the prank and had the players fooled hook, line and sinker. The alibi for the presence of cameras was that a “documentary on juco football was being shot.” Well played! As a sidenote, in eight years at the helm of the team, Coach Mooshagian has helped 174 student-athletes move on to the four-year level. They have won four consecutive conference championships and 16 titles overall.
Goff also deserves an Oscar for playing the role of an obnoxious transfer who thinks he’s better than everyone.
“Are you the punter?” he asked one unsuspecting player.
“No, I’m the quarterback,” was the response in a very awkward moment for the real QB, but super hilarious for us watching at home.

Goff went undercover with a hairy mole on his cheek, a wig and a set of tattoos on what otherwise is a clean, un-tatted body. On one side of his neck there was a big star (super cheesy), and on the other side was the motto of his high school (a nice, subtle nod to his alma mater).  On his arm was an image of his high school mascot. Why Dreaj Foge as his name? Dreaj is an anagram of Jared. Foge because … well, why not.

Goff, who was the first player picked in the 2016 NFL Draft, led the Rams to the playoffs in 2017 after a 13-year drought. The NFL's Most Improved Player had a breakout season with 3,804 passing yards and 28 touchdowns, while leading the league in yards per pass completion with 12.9.
Some might remember when Chicago Cubs baseball star
Kris Bryant transferred into a community college
back in 2016 to prank a team. This follows that same juicy plot. If you haven’t seen it, you simply must. You’re welcome.

contents.text: There aren’t many American cities that can call themselves a major hub for
fighting game

production, but Chicago is one that can. Home to Iron Galaxy and NetherRealm Studios, makers of games like Killer Instinct and Injustice, the Windy City boasts a strong community with roots in the fighting game industry.
With
Red Bull Conquest

’s first Rise event taking place in the Windy City this weekend, we take a look at Chicago’s welcoming and varied fighting game community, and get an insider’s perspective on what the historic locale has to offer for incoming fighters.

It’s no secret that Illinois is home to one of the biggest fighting game tournaments in the world. Combo Breaker, a pioneer of the 24-hour venue and a champion of smaller fighting game titles, was not always known by this name — it once went by UFGT (short for the straightforward Ultimate Fighting Game Tournament) and was a very different beast than the one we know today. While Rick “thehadou” Thiher may be the Event Director of Combo Breaker now, he inherited the tournament series from Adam Heart. Heart, who has since moved on to become a developer for Killer Instinct studio Iron Galaxy, was a mainstay of the Midwest scene.

“I’d become Assistant Director [of UFGT] alongside Max Wasserman,” Thiher explained. “During the development of UFGTX, Heart announced that he’d be retiring from tournament organizing to focus on other pursuits. Believing the Midwest couldn’t lose one of our large format tournaments, Max Wasserman and I forged a partnership with Gaming Generations and plotted out the event that would become COMBO BREAKER.”

With Heart’s blessing, Thiher was able to keep the UFGTX dream alive and build upon an already great event. “Heart, recognizing that Max and I were trying to carry forward event practices he’d helped standardized, was kind enough to allow me stage-time at UFGTX to announce COMBO BREAKER 2015,” Thiher recalled. “That passing of the torch, alongside a commitment to returning to UFGTX’s venue and end-of-May calendar placement, presented COMBO BREAKER as the Ultimate Fighting Game Tournament Series’ successor in the region.”

Since then, Combo Breaker has had a massive impact on the FGC, particularly with its overnight venue and welcoming atmosphere. “COMBO BREAKER’s greatest impact on the FGC was likely making late-night casuals and/or 24-hour venue areas a standard, which is something CB in turn thanks YOUMACON for inspiring,” Thiher said. “I think our event growth stems from the same things I believe people can look forward to each year; a vast number of tournament and casual setups, concert style staging, entertainment focused auction exhibitions, in-house commentary, deep dish pizza and a commitment to showcasing the many fighting game sub-genres as one collective spectacle.”

Aside from hosting one of the largest FGC events, Chicago is also one of the few cities in the United States with a dedicated competitive NetherRealm Studios gaming circuit. Tom Nieter, tournament organizer for the scene and a former professional NRS player, has been running the area’s Ghost Battle series since Injustice 1’s run in 2013.

“We are probably one of the few communities in the country that meets on a weekly basis in person,” he stated. “We have an eight-week season. At the end of the season, players compete in a round robin with the Top 8 seeds. We cut average attendance in half, so that the average season means more. We wanted players to treat the regular season more seriously.”

Neiter’s efforts to level up the community aren’t limited to the best of the best, though — those who don’t make the cut can still square off in what he calls a “best of the rest” tournament. For him, the series isn’t about gaining fame and glory: it’s about leveling up as a community. “Part of the inspiration behind the series is to be competitive and provide a fun, learning environment to level up in,” Neiter explained. “It’s not ever about the money--we just charge a $5 venue fee. It’s about the social aspect. We do streams and write-ups on our Facebook page for the winners of the weekly, and are one of the few outlets for the NRS scene.”

Neiter isn’t the only community leader running a local circuit in the area, either. Midwestern competitor and Frosty Faustings TO Elvenshadow runs a local endearingly dubbed Garage Gear. This Guilty Gear tournament is held every month out of his garage in the suburbs of Chicago, much in the grassroots style of the early FGC days. While not in the Conquest series, it provides ample community building, and hearkens to what makes the FGC so unique.
It also may be what breeds strong contenders for Guilty Gear at this weekend's Red Bull Conquest event.

A large part of the Midwest’s competitive scene can be traced back to Ghost Battle’s venue. The Galloping Ghost Arcade in Brookfield, Illinois, is more than a hub for players to gather and train — it is the largest arcade in the United States, holding over 180 World Records. The space also sponsored local players who wanted to attend major tournaments, and provided the community with the perfect place to level up.

“Our scene started in 2011, when the FGC was super grassroots still, and esports was just a joke,” Tom recalled. “Galloping Ghost sponsored an elite group of local players to travel and represent them. That’s where we started.”

Since then, Galloping Ghost has helped players score Top 8 placements at major events around the United States. “We aren’t as strong as we used to be,” Tom admitted, “but we’re still consistent, which is key when it comes to generating numbers and activity amongst players.”

Amanda “Romanova” Rose, celebrated FGC cosplayer and active member of the NRS scene, likewise holds the arcade in high regard. “Ignite Gaming Lounge and Galloping Ghost Arcade are two of my favorite venues,” she stated. “It’s a great place to check out when you’re in town for Combo Breaker! Our turnout is anywhere from 10-15 on average, and we all play Injustice 2 currently there.”

Of course, GGA isn’t the only venue on the menu: the Midwest also runs tournaments at the Ignite Gaming Lounge in Chicago, which will host Red Bull Conquest's first event on April 28th.. “Ignite does a little bit of everything, and is a great place to go to just to game in general,” Amanda said. “If you haven’t been there, check it out.”

Noah Vandercook, Chicago Tournament Organizer for the series, chose the spot due to its size and popularity for local tournaments. “It’s the biggest of its kind in the area, for weeklies and smaller events,” he explained. “It has been the place to go for seven or eight years. It has also hosted the previous year’s Red Bull Proving Grounds Chicago qualifiers. This time, we’re taking over the whole space for a much bigger event.” Tournament goers can look forward to the venue’s snack bar for food, shakes, and other treats, as well as specialized Red Bull concoctions. “We’ll have dedicated casual stations,” Noah added. “It’s good spot to meet everyone.”

Aside from unique venues, Chicago boasts a variety of players involved with different games in the fighting game community. “The community itself is really welcoming, with lots of variety,” Noah stated. “At Ignite, we have people who play Marvel and BlazBlue, and we have a thriving old-school arcade game community. There are so many different little communities. Almost every single one of them is really friendly, welcoming and strong.”
One of these strong players won nearly every single
Proving Grounds

tournament last year. Known as BxA CoolKid, he is one of the area’s favorites to take the year’s first Conquest tournament, and has nothing but good to speak of his local scene. “What makes the Chicago scene so special is how hungry we are,” he explained. “It really started to show when Red Bull first started doing the Proving Grounds events a year or two ago, I believe. Ever since then, I have seen players get so much better, and I can see it in their play how hungry and determined they are. We don't get as much exposure as other scenes, but we have some very good players here.”

CoolKid feels Chicago stands out from other local spots for its welcoming local community — but its pizza is worth an honorable mention, as well. “Players definitely gotta have some pizza when they come to Chicago, because that's what it's all about,” he laughed. “The pizza is ridiculous. Explore downtown Chicago, as well. It’s a beautiful city. Our players here are getting more hungry by the day. It'll only be a matter of time before others start to notice.”

title.text: Who will be crowned the champion of Chicago?

contents.text: Chicago has more to offer than pizza, however. Alongside the Navy Pier, Millennium Park and Cloud Gate waits a dedicated and varied fighting game community, with a love for local gatherings and an appreciation for the grassroots way of life. Be prepared to see a bit of everything at Conquest — between Street Fighter V, TEKKEN 7 and Guilty Gear Xrd REV2, the city has something for every competitor to enjoy.
Tune in this Saturday, April 28 at 2 p.m. CST on
twitch.tv/redbullesports
to catch the action!

RedBullConquest.com
for additional details and registration.

title.text: Chystané české VR projekty, které mohou mít celosvětový ohlas

contents.text: První seznámení s
virtuální realitou
rozhoduje o tom, zda se do technologie zamiluješ nebo ji naopak zapřeš.
Beat Saber
je v tomto ohledu perfektní volbou, která tě okamžitě vrhne do nefalšované
virtuální akce
. Popadneš světelné meče, nasadíš helmu a šviháš
do rytmu
elektronické hudby blížící se boxy. A věř, že po pár kolech před tvým
šermířským skillem
zbledne i sám
Yoda
Od 1. května bude Beat Sabre dostupný na
Steamu
a
Oculus Store
. K vyzkoušení bude i na
Czech VR Festu
Abys to ale neměl tak jednoduché, musíš do
boxíků
udeřit ve správnou chvíli, pod správným úhlem, ze správné strany a tím správným mečem. Že to zní komplikovaně? Ale kdeže, stačí
jeden
pohled
a hned víš,
kterou biješ
. Akorát si ke hraní připrav pořádnou zásobu energiťáků, protože takhle snadno se nezadýcháš ani při tektoniku.
S virtuální realitou
ošálíš
zrak, ale k omámení ostatních smyslů potřebuješ těžší
arzenál
. Zapomeň ale na kapačky s lehárem, abys okusil
Matrix
. Vyraž jen do
Prahy
na
Václavák
, kde v květnu vyroste stroj času, který tě přenese do rudolfínské Prahy, aby ses stal
císařovým pekařem
. Teprve tady poznáš, čeho je virtuální realita schopna.
Doma se u virtuální reality neprojdeš, válíš si šunky, dáváš majzla na délku kabelu a sáhnout si na ni nemůžeš, i kdybys vytáhl z kalhot
Masaryka
. V pražském
Hamley’s
se budeš pohybovat volně v prostoru a nebudeš jen bezvládně
zírat
a kazit si dojem ovladači. Rekvizity v celém objektu se postarají o to, aby jsi všechno, na co si sáhneš ve virtuální realitě, skutečně
cítil
ve svých rukou.
Na poli virtuálních atrakcí se tímto projektem staneme
prvními v Evropě
, ne-li ve světě.
Zabookuj si radši termín
co nejdříve, protože až se
Golem VR
rozkřikne, na Václaváku už se přes fronty nedostaneš ani ke stánku s klobásami. Tedy alespoň do té doby, než vývojáři z
DIVR Labs
rozšíří koncept do dalších zemí.
Cituješ
Hamleta
a v tu chvíli se zarazíš – tu lebku máš držet v levé nebo pravé ruce? Copak lebka, ale jmelí… Virtuální realita tě připraví na
divadelní inscenace
s takovou vervou, že ani nápovědy nebudeš potřebovat. Nasadíš
headset
, osvojíš si
scénář
své vytoužené divadelní role a poznáš, jaké to je být hercem. Tím ovšem ambice projektu
Theatre VR
od studia
Misterine
nekončí.
Založ si s přáteli
amatérský divadelní spolek
a začněte obrážet obýváky po celém světě svými vystoupeními. Zatím sice zinscenujete jenom osmiminutového Hamleta, ale než se nadějete, budete psát
vlastní
divadelní hry
a vydělávat si prodejem vstupenek ve vlastním virtuálním divadle.
O projekt
Theatre VR
už projevila zájem společnost
Merlin Entertainments
, která provozuje např. muzeum
Madame Tussauds
nebo
Legoland
. Voskové figuríny zřejmě brzy čeká obrození.
Viděl jsi někdy učebnice mediků? Na jejich
bichle
padla snad polovina amazonského pralesa. Přitom už půl tisíciletí víme, že
škola hrou
je daleko přínosnější než biflování abstraktních pojmů. V lidské anatomii to platí
dvojnásob
, protože lékaři nestačí jen teoretická znalost, ale především
praxe
. Tu je ovšem v reálném světě těžké sehnat, v tom virtuálním to je
hračka
Až tě bude operovat
zelenáč
, jistě budeš radši, když si tvé orgány osahal už na
virtuálním modelu
, než aby tě z narkózy probudila recitace jeho mnemotechnické pomůcky. Aplikace
Human Anatomy VR
od
Virtual Medicine
ti dovolí si rozbalit člověka jako cibuli, hezky vrstvu po vrstvě. Od kůže, přes svaly, po orgány až ke kostem.
Probádej své
orgánové soustavy
ostatně sám, aplikaci najdeš k dispozici zdarma na
Google Play
i
Oculus Store
. Zatím slouží primárně ke studiu, dlouhodobá vize je ovšem
reálné využití
v operačních přípravách a simulacích.
Virtuální realita má hranice bořit, ne je jen posunout k vizi někoho cizího. Jestli jsi
kreativní
, vykašli se na ostatní projekty a vytvoř si vlastní zašívárnu v
NeosVR
, kde tě limituje pouze vlastní představivost. Do této platformy si můžeš importovat
jakékoliv
3D modely, skeny a materiály. Ať už tedy toužíš po vlastním
Skyrimu
nebo jen po balení ženských na krásné
visty
, žhav své mozkové závity.
A když ne ty, tak někdo jiný. Uživatelé své světy mohou
sdílet
mezi sebou, vzájemně se
navštěvovat
, potkávat a společnými silami projekt i upravovat
v reálném čase
. Platforma se tak hodí i pro plánování rekonstrukcí nebo větších akcí – tímto způsobem třeba vznikl loňský
Czech VR Fest
Většina
tuzemských
projektů, které dobudou svět, se teprve kutí v garážích. Nemají žádnou
propagaci
, média je neznají a zatím stojí výhradně na myšlence a
odhodlání
začínajících podnikatelů
. Dnes už to bez pořádné investice nebo dostatečného finančního kapitálu jde bohužel
ztuha
. Řada
startupů
se tedy zúčastňuje veletrhů a předváděcích akcích, kde oslovuje svými projekty potenciální investory a sbírá zpětnou vazbu od nadšenců jako jsi
ty

title.text: Skaties kā Madars Apse un pārējie triecās cauri Peru

contents.text: Jau
skeitojuši izaicinošajās un dažreiz bīstamajās Limas un Kusko ielās
, un vēlāk kāpa augstu Andu kalnos, lai apmeklētu Maču Pikču, viņu ceļojums virzījās uz dienvidiem, cauri kalnu virsotnēm, līdz viņi sasniedza Peru pilsētu Puno.
Puno atrodas Titikakas ezera krastā, kurš ir augstākais kuģojamais ezers pasaulē.
Viņi atradās 3800m augstumā virs jūras līmeņa un gatavojās iepazīt skeitborda scēnu uz pasaules jumta.
Madars Apse
Taijnans Kosta, Andželo Karo
un
Miltons Martinezs
uzturēja skeitošanas tempus cik vien augstu spēja, tomēr
augstuma nelabums
sāka likt par sevi manīt: Taijnans kļuva par šīs biežās kondīcijas upuri un divas dienas pavadīja gultā, cīnoties ar pamatīgu nelabumu un drudzi.
Par laimi, Taijnans spēja atgūt spēkus pēc tam, kad pārējie trīs izpētīja daudzos, daudzos Puno piedāvātos spotus.
Peruvietis Andželo uzņēmās vadību un dienas laikā viņi atklāja unikālu skeitparku, kurš izbūvēts šķietamā telšu pilsētiņā.
Par laimi, vietējie viņus uzņēma un drīz vien turienes skeiteri pievienojās sesijai un izrādīja savus spotus.
Andželo vārds ir Peru skeitborda scēnā labi zināms un viņiem satikt viņu bija liels notikums.
Pēc vairākām dienām retinātā gaisā, viņiem vajadzēja veikli atgūt spēkus un tādēļ viņi devās Titikakas ezerā, lai satiktu tā iedzīvotājus - Uros.
Uros cilts dzīvoja izolācijā uz ezera gadsimtiem, apdzīvojot pašu būvētās peldošās salas un tās nepārtraukti atjaunojot no vietējām niedrēm.

Cilvēkiem ar pašiem savu izglītības sistēmu, valodu un kultūru, Uros ļoti iepatikās Madars. Viņi bija sajūsmā par šo bālo, balto, garo džeku, kuram bija pilnīgi vienalga par stindzinoši auksto ūdeni šajā augstumā.
Ar nelielām skumjām atvadoties no jaunajiem draugiem, bija laiks atgriezties uz dēļiem un doties uz Bolīviju, kura tagad bija vien akmeņa metiena attālumā uz dienvidiem.
Atgriezies nākamnedēļ, lai redzētu kā viņi ierodas Lapazā uz trakākajiem downhill, kādus pasaulē pieredzēsi - un ja palaidi garām viņu iepriekšējos piedzīvojumus Andos,
noskaties pirmo daļu ceļojumam, kurš sākās Limā, spiežot šeit
